elements.content: Unprecedented 1-D helical calcium−organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5, has been synthesized for the first time under hydrothermal reaction conditions using Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, (CH3)2NCOH, HNO3, and H2O as reagents. A complete characterization including the transformation of the helical chain with pincers to another helix with steps by the reaction with water is reported.
elements.clean_text: Unprecedented 1-D helical calcium-organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5, has been synthesized for the first time under hydrothermal reaction conditions using Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, (CH3)2NCOH, HNO3, and H2O as reagents. A complete characterization including the transformation of the helical chain with pincers to another helix with steps by the reaction with water is reported.

elements.content: Wire representations how the pincers-shape helical chain structure transforms. Once the coordinated water molecules are removed from the CAUMOF-4, the coordination sites in the Ca are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers and the more stable helix chain with PDC steps is obtained.
elements.clean_text: Wire representations how the pincers-shape helical chain structure transforms. Once the coordinated water molecules are removed from the CAUMOF-4, the coordination sites in the Ca are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers and the more stable helix chain with PDC steps is obtained.

elements.content: Metal−organic framework (MOF) materials have drawn enormous attention, attributable to their crucial applications in gas adsorption, isolation and separation of radioactive metal cations, sensing, and catalytic characteristics. Many synthetic chemists have been trying to tailor a wide variety of structural geometries, framework flexibilities and connectivities, and subsequent properties, such as gas adsorption, by tuning the combination of suitable metals and proper organic linkers. So far, main group, transition, rare-earth, and actinide metals have been used commonly to obtain novel metal−organic network topologies. Recently, some strategies have been reported, where the Ca is doped to the framework metals in order to increase the hydrogen storage by virtue of the stronger binding capability of Ca for H2. Of course, several Ca−organic framework materials have been synthesized as well. Most of the reported Ca−organic framework materials exhibit 3-D structures. During the course of investigation for numerous Ca−organic framework materials, we were able to synthesize a novel 1-D chain Ca−organic material with an interesting helical structure. Low-dimensional materials with helical geometries are extremely important in a variety of materials chemistry fields, such as separations, molecular recognitions, and biological systems. The rich structural architectures arising from the helical moieties are normally observed in polyoxometalates (POMs), microporous phosphates, metal−organic frameworks (MOFs), and metal oxyfluoride materials. Here, we would like to report a successful synthesis and characterization of a novel 1-D helical calcium−organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 (CAUMOF-4) and its interesting transformation reaction to Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)2 (CAUMOF-5).
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic framework (MOF) materials have drawn enormous attention, attributable to their crucial applications in gas adsorption, isolation and separation of radioactive metal cations, sensing, and catalytic characteristics. Many synthetic chemists have been trying to tailor a wide variety of structural geometries, framework flexibilities and connectivities, and subsequent properties, such as gas adsorption, by tuning the combination of suitable metals and proper organic linkers. So far, main group, transition, rare-earth, and actinide metals have been used commonly to obtain novel metal-organic network topologies. Recently, some strategies have been reported, where the Ca is doped to the framework metals in order to increase the hydrogen storage by virtue of the stronger binding capability of Ca for H2. Of course, several Ca-organic framework materials have been synthesized as well. Most of the reported Ca-organic framework materials exhibit 3-D structures. During the course of investigation for numerous Ca-organic framework materials, we were able to synthesize a novel 1-D chain Ca-organic material with an interesting helical structure. Low-dimensional materials with helical geometries are extremely important in a variety of materials chemistry fields, such as separations, molecular recognitions, and biological systems. The rich structural architectures arising from the helical moieties are normally observed in polyoxometalates (POMs), microporous phosphates, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), and metal oxyfluoride materials. Here, we would like to report a successful synthesis and characterization of a novel 1-D helical calcium-organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 (CAUMOF-4) and its interesting transformation reaction to Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)2 (CAUMOF-5).

elements.content: Ball-and-stick and space filling models representing a helical chain structure of CAUMOF-4 along the [001] direction. Note the dashed lines indicate the intrachain hydrogen bonds (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).
elements.clean_text: 1  Ball-and-stick and space filling models representing a helical chain structure of CAUMOF-4 along the [001] direction. Note the dashed lines indicate the intrachain hydrogen bonds (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).

elements.content: CAUMOF-4 has been synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, HCON(CH3)2, HNO3, and water at 180 °C for 3 days. Colorless rod crystals have been recovered as a single phase. CAUMOF-4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (No. 15). CAUMOF-4 shows unidimensional helical chains consisting of CaO6N polyhedra and 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate (PDC) organic groups (see Figure ). The unique Ca2+ cation is connected to four oxygen and one nitrogen atoms in the equatorial positions and two oxygen atoms in the axial positions. Thus, a seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is observed around the Ca2+ cation. The five equatorial ligands consist of three oxygen atoms from the carboxylates, one nitrogen atom from the pyridine, and one oxygen atom from the water, and each of the axial oxygen ligands is from the water and the carboxylate group. The Ca−O and Ca−N bond distances are 2.303(3)−2.481(3) and 2.468(3) Å, respectively. Bond valence calculations on the CAUMOF-4 resulted in a value of 2.08 for the Ca2+ cation. The carboxylate groups in the organic linker PDC are connected to the calcium cations through oxygen and nitrogen atoms. The C−O bond distances range from 1.246(4) to 1.276(5) Å, and the C−N bond lengths range from 1.341(5) to 1.349(5) Å within the PDC linker.
elements.clean_text: CAUMOF-4 has been synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, HCON(CH3)2, HNO3, and water at 180 °C for 3 days. Colorless rod crystals have been recovered as a single phase. CAUMOF-4 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c (No. 15). CAUMOF-4 shows unidimensional helical chains consisting of CaO6N polyhedra and 2,6-pyridine dicarboxylate (PDC) organic groups (see Figure ). The unique Ca2+ cation is connected to four oxygen and one nitrogen atoms in the equatorial positions and two oxygen atoms in the axial positions. Thus, a seven-coordinate pentagonal bipyramidal geometry is observed around the Ca2+ cation. The five equatorial ligands consist of three oxygen atoms from the carboxylates, one nitrogen atom from the pyridine, and one oxygen atom from the water, and each of the axial oxygen ligands is from the water and the carboxylate group. The Ca-O and Ca-N bond distances are 2.303(3)-2.481(3) and 2.468(3) Å, respectively. Bond valence calculations on the CAUMOF-4 resulted in a value of 2.08 for the Ca2+ cation. The carboxylate groups in the organic linker PDC are connected to the calcium cations through oxygen and nitrogen atoms. The C-O bond distances range from 1.246(4) to 1.276(5) Å, and the C-N bond lengths range from 1.341(5) to 1.349(5) Å within the PDC linker.

elements.content: Ball-and-stick and space filling models representing a pair of pincer-shaped structure of CAUMOF-4. Note the two CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups with PDC linkers are joined by a bridging water molecule (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).
elements.clean_text: 2  Ball-and-stick and space filling models representing a pair of pincer-shaped structure of CAUMOF-4. Note the two CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups with PDC linkers are joined by a bridging water molecule (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).

elements.content: The CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups share their edges through the equatorial oxygen atoms [O(3)] of the PDC and form the edge-sharing Ca2O10N2 dimers. Then the PDC groups link to the Ca2O10N2 dimers along the approximate [010] and [0−10] directions. Interestingly, the carboxylate groups of the PDC ligands are further coordinated to the other Ca2O10N2 dimers through the axial oxygen atoms and form a novel calcium−organic unidimensional helical chain structure that runs parallel to the [001] axis (see Figure ). As seen in Figure , the two CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups with PDC linkers are joined by a bridging water molecule [H2O(2)], which makes the shape look like a pair of pincers or castanets. Thus, pyridine rings in the coordinated PDC ligands might have significant π−π stacking interactions as well. Strong intrachain hydrogen bonds are observed between the carboxylate oxygen atoms and axial water molecules [O(1)···O(6), 2.780(7) Å] (see dashed lines drawn in Figure ). The intrachain hydrogen bonding interactions might be responsible for the helical chain geometry of CAUMOF-4. In addition, we also observe that strong interchain hydrogen bonds occur from the carboxylate oxygen atoms and axial water molecules [O(1)···O(6), 2.710(17) Å], which result in a pseudo-two-dimensional topology of CAUMOF-4.
elements.clean_text: The CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups share their edges through the equatorial oxygen atoms [O(3)] of the PDC and form the edge-sharing Ca2O10N2 dimers. Then the PDC groups link to the Ca2O10N2 dimers along the approximate [010] and [0-10] directions. Interestingly, the carboxylate groups of the PDC ligands are further coordinated to the other Ca2O10N2 dimers through the axial oxygen atoms and form a novel calcium-organic unidimensional helical chain structure that runs parallel to the [001] axis (see Figure ). As seen in Figure , the two CaO6N pentagonal bipyramidal groups with PDC linkers are joined by a bridging water molecule [H2O(2)], which makes the shape look like a pair of pincers or castanets. Thus, pyridine rings in the coordinated PDC ligands might have significant π-π stacking interactions as well. Strong intrachain hydrogen bonds are observed between the carboxylate oxygen atoms and axial water molecules [O(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6), 2.780(7) Å] (see dashed lines drawn in Figure ). The intrachain hydrogen bonding interactions might be responsible for the helical chain geometry of CAUMOF-4. In addition, we also observe that strong interchain hydrogen bonds occur from the carboxylate oxygen atoms and axial water molecules [O(1)⋅⋅⋅O(6), 2.710(17) Å], which result in a pseudo-two-dimensional topology of CAUMOF-4.

elements.content: The infrared spectrum of the material exhibits CH and CC stretches of the pyridine ring of PDC at ca. 3090 and 1566−1592 cm−1, respectively. The vibrations about 1370−1589 cm−1 may be assigned to the CO2 stretches in the carboxylate group. The vibrations for the water molecules are also observed around 3363 cm−1. The assignments are consistent with those previously reported.
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectrum of the material exhibits CH and CC stretches of the pyridine ring of PDC at ca. 3090 and 1566-1592 cm-1, respectively. The vibrations about 1370-1589 cm-1 may be assigned to the CO2 stretches in the carboxylate group. The vibrations for the water molecules are also observed around 3363 cm-1. The assignments are consistent with those previously reported.

elements.content: Thermal analysis of CAUMOF-4 shows a weight loss of 10.1% between room temperature and 310 °C that is attributable to the loss of the water molecules from the material (calc 11.6%). The framework of the material seems to be stable up to 450 °C. Above this temperature, the material starts decomposing, and the framework collapses by 800 °C. The thermal decomposition product at 800 °C for CAUMOF-4 resulted in CaCO3, which was determined by powder X-ray diffraction measurement.
elements.clean_text: Thermal analysis of CAUMOF-4 shows a weight loss of 10.1% between room temperature and 310 °C that is attributable to the loss of the water molecules from the material (calc 11.6%). The framework of the material seems to be stable up to 450 °C. Above this temperature, the material starts decomposing, and the framework collapses by 800 °C. The thermal decomposition product at 800 °C for CAUMOF-4 resulted in CaCO3, which was determined by powder X-ray diffraction measurement.

elements.content: Wire representations how the pincer-shaped helical chain structure transforms. Once the coordinated water molecules are removed from the CAUMOF-4, the coordination sites in the Ca are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers, and the more stable helix chain with PDC steps is obtained (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).
elements.clean_text: 3  Wire representations how the pincer-shaped helical chain structure transforms. Once the coordinated water molecules are removed from the CAUMOF-4, the coordination sites in the Ca are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers, and the more stable helix chain with PDC steps is obtained (yellow, Ca; blue, N; red, O; gray, C).

elements.content: An interesting characteristic of the material is the transformation of CAUMOF-4 to a new phase, CAUMOF-5, with the accompanying loss and gain of H2O. This transformation is shown schematically in Figure . Initially, the single crystals of CAUMOF-4 were heated at 310 °C for 3 h under vacuum to remove the coordinated water molecules. Then the activated sample was immersed in water and heated to 70 °C for 10 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C/h, colorless crystals of CAUMOF-5 with completely different chain structures were obtained, which were identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. As soon as the CAUMOF-4 was heated up, the coordinated water molecules were removed, just like the tied strings are loosened (see Figure ). Then the coordination sites in the Ca for incoming water molecules are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers, and the more stable new helical chain material, CAUMOF-5, is crystallized. While a similar chain of edge-sharing Ca2O10N2 dimers is observed in CAUMOF-5 as well, the PDC linkers are connected to the chain on both sides, above and below. As seen in Figure , the CAUMOF-5 exhibits a novel helical chain structure with PDC steps.
elements.clean_text: An interesting characteristic of the material is the transformation of CAUMOF-4 to a new phase, CAUMOF-5, with the accompanying loss and gain of H2O. This transformation is shown schematically in Figure . Initially, the single crystals of CAUMOF-4 were heated at 310 °C for 3 h under vacuum to remove the coordinated water molecules. Then the activated sample was immersed in water and heated to 70 °C for 10 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C/h, colorless crystals of CAUMOF-5 with completely different chain structures were obtained, which were identified by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. As soon as the CAUMOF-4 was heated up, the coordinated water molecules were removed, just like the tied strings are loosened (see Figure ). Then the coordination sites in the Ca for incoming water molecules are spontaneously opened up by the rotation of PDC linkers, and the more stable new helical chain material, CAUMOF-5, is crystallized. While a similar chain of edge-sharing Ca2O10N2 dimers is observed in CAUMOF-5 as well, the PDC linkers are connected to the chain on both sides, above and below. As seen in Figure , the CAUMOF-5 exhibits a novel helical chain structure with PDC steps.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized novel calcium−organic framework materials with helical chain structures. Additional experiments using other alkaline earth metals and organic linkers are ongoing and will be reported shortly.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have successfully synthesized and characterized novel calcium-organic framework materials with helical chain structures. Additional experiments using other alkaline earth metals and organic linkers are ongoing and will be reported shortly.

elements.content: Crystallographic data in CIF format, experimental and calculated powder XRD patterns, infrared spectrum, and thermogravimetric analysis diagram for Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.
elements.clean_text: Crystallographic data in CIF format, experimental and calculated powder XRD patterns, infrared spectrum, and thermogravimetric analysis diagram for Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

elements.content: Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 was synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2 (0.296 g, 4.00 × 10−3 mol), 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2 (0.167 g, 1.00 × 10−3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (3 mL), HNO3 (1 mL), and H2O (3 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h−1. The autoclave was opened, and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-4 in 85% yield based on Ca(OH)2.
elements.clean_text:
References

Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 was synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2 (0.296 g, 4.00 × 10-3 mol), 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2 (0.167 g, 1.00 × 10-3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (3 mL), HNO3 (1 mL), and H2O (3 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h-1. The autoclave was opened, and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-4 in 85% yield based on Ca(OH)2.

elements.content: A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 mm × 0.12 mm × 0.28 mm for CAUMOF-4 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at 200 K using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The data were integrated using the SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz, polarization, air absorption, and absorption attributable to the variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. A semiempirical absorption correction was made on the hemisphere of data with the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97. Crystal data: monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15) with a = 13.658(3) Å, b = 9.837(2) Å, c = 13.586(3) Å, β = 92.64(3)°, V = 1823.3(6) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalc = 1.684 g cm−3, 2θmax = 56.0°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 200.0(2) K, total data 6505, unique data 2191, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1292, μ = 0.69 mm−1, 152 parameters, R int = 0.0774, observed R(F)/R w(F) = 0.0497/0.0906 on |F 2|.
elements.clean_text: A colorless rod crystal of dimension 0.10 mm × 0.12 mm × 0.28 mm for CAUMOF-4 was used for structural determination. Data were collected on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD X-ray diffractometer at the Korea Basic Science institute at 200 K using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The data were integrated using the SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for Lorentz, polarization, air absorption, and absorption attributable to the variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. A semiempirical absorption correction was made on the hemisphere of data with the SADABS program. The structures were solved by direct methods using SHELXS-97 and refined using SHELXL-97. Crystal data: monoclinic, space group C2/c (No. 15) with a = 13.658(3) Å, b = 9.837(2) Å, c = 13.586(3) Å, β = 92.64(3)°, V = 1823.3(6) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalc = 1.684 g cm-3, 2θmax = 56.0°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 200.0(2) K, total data 6505, unique data 2191, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1292, μ = 0.69 mm-1, 152 parameters, R int = 0.0774, observed R(F)/R w(F) = 0.0497/0.0906 on |F 2|.

elements.content: Crystal data: monoclinic, space group P21/n (No. 14), a = 5.8693(12) Å, b = 17.848(4) Å, c = 9.897(2) Å, β = 98.62(3)°, V = 1025.1(4) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalc = 1.680 g cm−3, 2θmax = 51.0°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 200.0(2) K, total data 6114, unique data 1905, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1335, μ = 0.633 mm−1, 165 parameters, R int = 0.0582, observed R(F)/R w(F) = 0.0442/0.0927 on |F 2|.

cln_elements.content:
Unprecedented 1-D helical calcium−organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5, has been synthesized for the first time under hydrothermal reaction conditions using Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, (CH3)2NCOH, HNO3, and H2O as reagents. A complete characterization including the transformation of the helical chain with pincers to another helix with steps by the reaction with water is reported.

References

Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 was synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2 (0.296 g, 4.00 × 10−3 mol), 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2 (0.167 g, 1.00 × 10−3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (3 mL), HNO3 (1 mL), and H2O (3 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h−1. The autoclave was opened, and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-4 in 85% yield based on Ca(OH)2.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Unprecedented 1-D helical calcium-organic framework material, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5, has been synthesized for the first time under hydrothermal reaction conditions using Ca(OH)2, 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2, (CH3)2NCOH, HNO3, and H2O as reagents. A complete characterization including the transformation of the helical chain with pincers to another helix with steps by the reaction with water is reported.

References

Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5 was synthesized by combining Ca(OH)2 (0.296 g, 4.00 × 10-3 mol), 2,6-NC5H3(CO2H)2 (0.167 g, 1.00 × 10-3 mol), HCON(CH3)2 (3 mL), HNO3 (1 mL), and H2O (3 mL). The reaction mixture was transferred to a Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave. The autoclave was subsequently sealed and heated to 180 °C for 3 days, before being cooled to room temperature at a rate of 6 °C h-1. The autoclave was opened, and the product was recovered by filtration and washed with ethanol. Colorless rod crystals were recovered for CAUMOF-4 in 85% yield based on Ca(OH)2.

cln_elements.content:
Thermal analysis of CAUMOF-4 shows a weight loss of 10.1% between room temperature and 310 °C that is attributable to the loss of the water molecules from the material (calc 11.6%). The framework of the material seems to be stable up to 450 °C. Above this temperature, the material starts decomposing, and the framework collapses by 800 °C. The thermal decomposition product at 800 °C for CAUMOF-4 resulted in CaCO3, which was determined by powder X-ray diffraction measurement.

Crystal data: monoclinic, space group P21/n (No. 14), a = 5.8693(12) Å, b = 17.848(4) Å, c = 9.897(2) Å, β = 98.62(3)°, V = 1025.1(4) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalc = 1.680 g cm−3, 2θmax = 51.0°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 200.0(2) K, total data 6114, unique data 1905, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1335, μ = 0.633 mm−1, 165 parameters, R int = 0.0582, observed R(F)/R w(F) = 0.0442/0.0927 on |F 2|.

The thermal decomposition product at 800 °C for CAUMOF-4 resulted in CaCO3, which was determined by powder X-ray diffraction measurement.

Crystal data: monoclinic, space group P21/n (No. 14), a = 5.8693(12) Å, b = 17.848(4) Å, c = 9.897(2) Å, β = 98.62(3)°, V = 1025.1(4) Å3, Z = 4, ρcalc = 1.680 g cm-3, 2θmax = 51.0°, λ = 0.71073 Å, T = 200.0(2) K, total data 6114, unique data 1905, observed data (I > 2σ(I)) = 1335, μ = 0.633 mm-1, 165 parameters, R int = 0.0582, observed R(F)/R w(F) = 0.0442/0.0927 on |F 2|.

metadata.title: From Pincers to Steps: Synthesis, Structure, Characterization, and Transformation of a New Helical Calcium−Organic Framework, Ca[NC5H3(CO2)2](H2O)1.5
